Column: 93

[Mr Speaker in the Chair]

ORAL ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS

SINGAPORE TELEPHONE BOARD
(Introduction of "ten cents a call" system)


    1. Mr Low Yong Nguan asked the Minister for Communications whether he is aware of protests from telephone subscribers against the proposed "ten-cent-a-call" system, and if he will give a categorical assurance that the proposed system will not be proceeded with.

    The Minister for Communications (Mr Yong Nyuk Lin): Mr Speaker, Sir, I have been reading press speculation to the effect that the Singapore Telephone

Column: 94

Board would be introducing a "ten cents a call" system for telephones otherwise known as the Message rate system.

    As explained in the Addendum to the President's speech, operational surpluses of the S.T.B. average only $12 million a year on existing rentals. Not all of the balance of $160 million for development can be borrowed, so it will be necessary for the S.T.B, to increase its rentals.

    The S.T.B, has the problem of finding adequate finance to meet its large five-year development programme for 197l-75 amounting to $212 million. So far, the World Bank has agreed to assist with a loan of $33 million or just over 15 per cent of total development.

Column: 95



    Various alternatives of raising revenue equitably are under consideration by the SIB. The Message rate is one of the methods.

    In advanced countries the method of charging is related to frequency of calls as well as the length of each call. It can be made fairer still by charging less for calls during off-peak hours, as in the case of trunk calls.

    Unfortunately, we have not yet achieved that degree of sophistication in our equipment, nor do we have as yet professional expertise to maintain such equipment. Within five to 10 years we hope to achieve this. Then people will pay in accordance with the load they put on the telephone network. This will help to cut out jams on Saturday mornings and race days, besides making the charges fairer.

    Meanwhile, it has been decided that the annual telephone rentals of residential and business Direct Exchange Lines he increased from $180 to $200 and from $250 to $300 respectively with effect from 1st October, 1971.

    Mr Low Yong Nguan (Crawford): Mr Speaker, Sir, it looks like the Message rate system will not be introduced for some time to come.

    Sir, I have a few supplementary questions to ask. First, will the Minister consider issuing public bonds by tile S.T.B, to meet part of the development cost? Second, will the Minister let the I-louse know whether tile new rates are final and that there are no grounds for further negotiation, or will he consult business organisations before finalising tile rates? Lastly, has his Ministry done any evaluation on the new rates and, if so, how do they compare with the charges under the Message late system as practised, say, in a country like Malaysia?

    Mr Yong Nyuk Lin: Mr Speaker, Sir, I will attempt to reply to the three supplementary questions. First, whether there will be more public telephones to be installed. We already have no less than 2,000 public telephones at ten cents per call, and we have another

Column: 96

2,000 in hand which will he made available to the public soon, and we intend to increase the number of public telephones in Singapore.

    As regards the second supplementary question. whether the increased rentals with effect from 1st October, 1971 will be final. The answer is that they are final and there will be no further negotiation or discussions with interested groups.

    Thirdly whether evaluation has been made on the proposed increased rentals with effect from October of this year, I can say that the new telephone rentals, even with the prevailing Government tax of 15 per cent, will compare favourably with telephone rentals now charged in West Malaysia. We have not made any attempt to find out what goes on in East Malaysia because a sea of about 800 miles separates the two countries. So I think we can only talk about West Malaysia where it is possible for us to have subscriber direct dialling service available to those in Singapore. As regards charges in West Malaysia subscribers do pay annual rentals of $204 for a residential telephone and $360 for a business telephone. They also pay, in addition, a surcharge of ten cents a call after the first one hundred calls. Furthermore, residential subscribers are also required to deposit $75 while the deposit required for a business subscriber ranges from $200 to $500.

    Mr Low Yong Nguan: I am satisfied with the answers to the last two questions. Sir, but perhaps the Minister has missed my first question. It is whether either his Ministry or the S.T.B. will consider issuing public bonds to meet part of the development cost.

    Mr Yong Nyuk Lin: I am sorry if my ears have failed to catch the words "public bonds". I thought I heard "public telephones". Nevertheless. I did say earlier that various alternatives of raising revenue equitably are under consideration by the Singapore Telephone Board. Therefore, the issuance of public bonds will be considered.

Column: 97



    Tuan Haji Mohd. Ariff Bin Suradi (Kampong Kembangan): Mr Speaker. Sir, is the Minister aware that many telephone subscribers are dissatisfied with the S.T.B, billing system which has led to a temporary disconnection of their lines recently? Also, is the payment of $5.75 for re-connection justifiable?

    Mr Speaker: Is the Minister prepared to answer that supplementary question which is riot quite related to the original question?

    Mr Yong Nyuk Lin: Mr Speaker. Sir, it does not appear to be an extension of the original question. However considering the fact that the Member for Kampong Kembangan happens to work in the Singapore Telephone Board, he has therefore much more inside information than 1 have. To his first supplementary question whether I am aware of any dissatisfaction. I must say that I am not aware of that. Now that he has brought it to my notice, I will request the management of the S.T.B, to look further into the question to removes the grievances, if any.

Column: 97

SCHOOLS IN VICINITY OF PALEMBANG ROAD
(Demolition)


    2. Mr Low Yong Nguan asked the Minister for Education whether existing schools in the vicinity of the present Palembang Housing Estate will be demolished as a result of urban renewal. and whether there are plans to build new schools in the area.

    The Minister of State for Education (Dr Lee Chiaw Meng) (for the Minister for Education): Mr Speaker. Sir, my Ministers has not been informed whether any school in the vicinity of Palembang Road which is in Precinct North I, has been earmarked for demolition. However, I would like to assure the Member for Crawford that my Ministry will adhere to the principle of rebuilding schools to replace those to be demolished in areas where the number of pupils does not decline as a result of urban renewal projects. The Member for

Column: 98

Crawford may like to know also that recently we have reserved a site for a primary school in that locality.

    Mr Low Yong Nguan: Mr Speaker. Sir, can the Minister of State for Education assure us that if the school to he demolished is an aided school, then an aided school will be rebuilt from funds raised from the public? Or will only a Government school be rebuilt to accommodate the students?

    Dr Lee Chiaw Meng: Mr Speaker. Sir, each case will he considered on its own merits, even in respect of aided schools. It depends on the demand of that locality.

Column: 98

PROSTITUTES DETAINED AND TRAINED IN WELFARE HOMES
(Particulars)


    3. Inche Rahmat Bin Kenap Al-Haj asked the Minister for Social Affairs how many prostitutes were referred to and detained in the approved homes of the Social Welfare Department between 1st. July 1970 and the latest convenient date: for how long are they detained: and what trades are they being taught in such homes.

    The Minister for Social Affairs (Inche Othman Bin Wok): Mr Speaker. Sir, the Mount Emily Girls' Home is tile only Home run by the Social Welfare Department for the reception and training of juvenile prostitutes up to the age of 21 years.

    During the period from 1st July. 1970 to 30th June. 1971, a total of 84 girls were rescued by the Police during anti-vice raids and referred to the Social Welfare Department for inquiry under the provisions of Part X of the Women's Charter.

    After inquiry 64 of the girls were discharged for various reasons and the remaining 20 girls were committed to the Mount Emily Girls' Home for protection and rehabilitation.

    Under the law, a girl may be detained until she attains the age of 21 years or

Column: 99

marries, whichever is the earlier. However, the length of detention depends largely on the circumstances of each case. In the majority of cases, the period of stay in the Mount Emily Girls' Home is between 1½ and 2½ years.

    The training provided for the girls at the Home includes courses in laundry-work, cooking, cake-making, food-catering, sewing and dress-making hygiene, civics, ethics and morality. The Department has also just introduced advanced, courses in cooking and dress-making. New courses on ladies' hair-dressing and beautician courses leading to the diploma level are also being introduced The sole purpose of these new advanced courses is to enable the residents of the Home to earn a stable and decent living upon their discharge from the Home.

    Inche Rahmat Bin Kenap Al-Haj (Geylang Serai)(In Malay): Mr Speaker. Sir, can the Minister explain why the 64 girls referred to were discharged?

    Inche Othman Bin Wok: Mr Speaker, Sir, the 64 girls referred to were discharged for the following reasons:

(1) being above the age of 21 years, they are, therefore, not liable for detention;

(2) being almost 21 years of age at the time of rescue, their detention in the Home would have achieved very little purpose;

(3) being lawfully married persons, they are, therefore, not liable for detention;

(4) being Malaysian citizens or residents. or illegal immigrants from Thailand or Indonesia: as far as possible, their early repatriation was arranged with the help of the Immigration Department;

(5) insufficient or no evidence available regarding their involvement in immoral activities.

    Inche Rahmat Bin Kenap Al-Haj(In Malay): Mr Speaker, Sir, call a girl

Column: 100

who is detained in the Mount Emily Girls' Home be examined by a doctor to determine her state of health? Are her parents allowed to visit her?

    Inche Othman Bin Wok: Sir, this is becoming more interesting! Immediately after a girl is brought to the Mount Emily Girls' Home following an anti-vice raid, she is sent to the reception centre in the Home itself. She remains there, away from contact with the other girls in the Home, until she is medically cleared of infectious disease. Once cleared, she is either discharged if there are no grounds for detention, or sent to the main Home for training and rehabilitation. And during her stay in the Home, every attempt is made to keep her in frequent contact with members of her family. Weekend visits by members of the family are also allowed in most cases.

    Inche Rahmat Bin Kenap Al-Haj: Sir, if a girl who is detained desires to continue with her studies, will she be given the facilities to do so?

    Inche Othman Bin Wok: Sir, should a girl during her stay in the Mount Emily Girls' Home express a desire to continue with her studies, every attempt is made to help her by giving her a transfer to the Mary mount Vocational Centre where she can resume her studies and prepare herself for the School Certificate. Financial help is also given to her if, after obtaining the School Certificate. she expresses a keen desire to go for higher studies.

Column: 100

GOVERNMENT HOSPITALS
(24-hour visit system in children's wards)


    4. Mr Teong Eng Siong asked the Minister for Health if he is considering implementing a 24-hour visit system in children's wards in all Government hospitals, as this would permit parents to assist in looking after their children: and whether it is possible to provide beds for visitors who stay overnight.

    The Minister for Health (Mr Chua Sian Chin): Mr Speaker. Sir, a 24-hour visit system for parents wishing to visit

Column: 101

their children in the children's ward is already implemented in all the children's wards in the Outram Road General Hospital. Where it is necessary for the parents to stay overnight, a mother's room is also available. There are no children's wards in the other Government hospitals.

    At the St. Andrew's Orthopaedic Hospital, the children are sent to convalesce from orthopaedic and other medical conditions. As this is a convalescent hospital, the sole purpose is the giving of continued medical attention and nursing care, which cannot be provided for at home. Children are encouraged to have regular habits with regular exercise, rest periods and meal times. Time for schoolwork, physiotherapy and occupational therapy has also to be set aside. The habit of early sleeping hours is encouraged. In the circumstances, it would be difficult to achieve this if parents are allowed to come in and upset the normal timetable as well as distract other children, as the wards are open wards.

    Mr Teong Eng Siong (Sembawang)(In Mandarin): Mr Speaker, Sir, I know that the 24-hour visit system is implemented in the Outram Road General Hospital. But I would like to know whether this system is also implemented in the other hospitals.

    Mr Chua Sian Chin: Sir, may I just repeat what I have said just now? There are no children's wards in the other Government hospitals.

    Mr Teong Eng Siong(In Mandarin): Sir, can the Minister for Health assure the House that when a children's ward is set up in any Government hospital, this 24-hour visit system will be implemented?

    Mr Speaker: Question No. 5, Mr Low.

Column: 101

PALEMBANG HOUSING ESTATE
(Building of out-patient clinic)


    5. Mr Low Yong Nguan asked the Minister for Health whether an outpatient clinic will be built in the vicinity

Column: 102

of the present Palembang Housing Estate.

    Mr Chua Sian Chin: Mr Speaker, Sir, the residents of Palembang Housing Estate should find no difficulty in getting outpatient service at the Kallang and Kampong Bugis Outpatient Dispensaries, both of which are within one mile distance from the Housing Estate.

    It is estimated that there are at present about 12,290 people living in the aforementioned area. However, on completion of the redevelopment of the area within the next five years, there would be a population of 30,000. These two outpatient dispensaries could still easily cater for this increased number of residents.

    No new outpatient clinic will, therefore, be built in Palembang Housing Estate.

    Mr Low Yong Nguan: Mr Speaker. Sir, of the two outpatient clinics mentioned by the Minister, I suspect that at least one of them will be demolished within the next few years. If so, can the Minister consider building a clinic on the centre of this area to cater for the residents of the housing estate?

    Mr Chua Sian Chin: Mr Speaker. Sir, am not aware that one of the clinics will be demolished within the next few years. But if it is going to be demolished, alternative arrangements will, of course, be made.

Column: 102

PROSTITUTES APPREHENDED
(Particulars)


    6. Inche Rahmat Bin Kenap Al-Haj asked the Minister for Home Affairs how many prostitutes were apprehended between 1st July. 1970, and the latest convenient date; and how many of them were (i) below the age of 21: (ii) Singapore citizens; and (iii) non-citizens.

    The Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Home Affairs (Mr L. P. Rodrigo) (for the Minister for Home Affairs): Mr Speaker, Sir, between the 1st of July, 1970, and the 26th of July. 1971, a total of 11 prostitutes were

Column: 103

arrested for soliciting in public and 84 juvenile prostitutes were rescued from brothels. All those arrested are Singapore citizens above the age of 21. Of the 84 juvenile prostitutes. 55 are Singapore citizens and the remaining 29 are non-Singapore citizens.

    Inche Rahmat Bin Kenap Al-Haj(In Malay): Sir, can the Parliamentary Secretary say whether these prostitutes were using hotels or private houses for soliciting?

    Mr Rodrigo: Mr Speaker, Sir, as stated in my answer, these prostitutes were arrested for soliciting in public and presumably, therefore, they were arrested on public roads.

    Inche Rahmat Bin Kenap Al-Haj(In Malay): Sir, can the Parliamentary Secretary tell the House whether the prostitutes arrested were first-class or second-class prostitutes?

    Mr Rodrigo: Mr Speaker. Sir, my Ministry does not classify prostitutes, nor does it have anything to do with the classification of prostitutes. This perhaps would he within the general knowledge of the Member himself!

    Inche Rahmat Bin Kenap Al-Haj(In Malay): Sir, can the Parliamentary Secretary inform the House where most of these prostitutes were found?

    Mr Rodrigo: Sir, I fancy this question does not fall within the ambit of the original question, and I would like notice so as to be able to give the hon. Member the correct figures.

Column: 103

ADJOURNMENT MOTION
(Business Motion)

    "That not withstanding the Standing Orders.

Column: 104

PRESIDENT'S SPEECH

Debate on the Address
(Second Day)


    Order read for resuming adjourned debate on Question [30th July. 1971].

    `That the following Address in reply to the speech of the President be agreed to: -

    "We, the Parliament of the Republic of Singapore, express our thanks to the President for the speech which he de, livered on behalf of the Government at the opening of the Second Session at this Parliament.".'. - [Dr Chiang Hai Ding].

    Question again proposed.

2.55 p.m.

    The Minister of State for Foreign Affairs (Inche A. Rahim Ishak): Mr Speaker, Sir, the story is told of the President of Ireland. Eamon de Valera. that he was once arrested in the middle of what the authorities considered a subversive speech and sentenced to a year's imprisonment. On his release, being a true Irishman of American and Cuban extraction, he returned to the same spot where he was arrested and began his speech with the words: "As I was saying when I was interrupted...".

Column: 105



    Mr Speaker, Sir,I can assure you that as a true Singaporean of Malay extraction. I was not arrested and imprisoned between 4.30 p.m, on Friday and noon today either for any political or criminal offence. [Laughter] Although I was at Changi during the week-end, it was nowhere near what the Minister for Home Affairs calls "Moon Crescent". [Laughter] I simply wish to continue with the speech I made last week.

    President Nixon's move as announced on the 16th of July will, I think, lead to the establishment of relations with the People's, Republic of China. This development is historically inevitable. The United States can no longer ignore the political and legal existence, of China, just as China `has to recognise that she is living in a big world with two super-powers and other big powers. And although the latest American move has partly to do with the American position in relation to the war in Vietnam, it has in fact taken place because the policy the United States formulated for itself vis-a-vis China 22 years ago is becoming less relevant as the world has changed much since then. It was the United States which formulated this policy of recognising the Republic of China under Chiang Kai Shek and it is the United States which now wants to undo this policy.

    More than 20 years ago America was the victor in the war and she was then the only super-power in the world. And she considered the Soviet Union as her No. 1 enemy. The United States believed herself to be lighting the Soviet Union in China. Korea, Vietnam and elsewhere. But over the years. the United States has realised, albeit belatedly, that what, ever policy China is conducting is on her own behalf and for her own interest. This has become all the more evident to her since China breached with the Soviet Union, it would appear that the United States is moving towards an accommodation with China as an increasingly strong independent power, just as she has been seeking accommodation

Column: 106

with the Soviet Union to reduce conflicts.

    For China, her policies are also changing. The United States is no longer regarded as the No. 1 enemy in interstate relations, although what she calls "American imperialism" might still be considered its ideological adversary. This is indicated clearly in speeches and broadcasts made by the leaders of the People's Republic of China. During the last five to six years China has become a nuclear power. This is an important factor to consider as China cannot from now onwards conduct diplomacy like when she was just a military power. From now China has to conduct power politics by the normal, international channels and the best way for her to do this is to join the United Nations. To this extent, China could be' considered sincere in her desire to join the. U.N, a:; she gradually picks up the old Leninist slogan of peaceful co-existence and peaceful competition between states with different social systems.

    China's entry into the United Nations is inevitable. China is a big power, as said on 30th July, 1971, and Singapore cannot influence international events. There will be no change in Singapore's attitude towards what is called the "important question" issue on the entry of China in the United Nations. Singapore has always supported China's entry into the U.N.' WQ abstained on the Albanian resolution previously because the first part of that resolution, in our view, needed to be decided first before the second part could be decided upon. We believe that once China is admitted, the possibilities are that she will take her seat and automatically become a member of the Security Council.

    Singapore's attitude is that as a small power our policy is to adjust to big realities created by the big powers. Singapore does not want to be under the influence of one power. There are, in any case, many powers around us which want to pursue their economic and other interests. The competition amongst the big powers is for markets and security' interests which are in fact legitimate

Column: 107

objectives to pursue. Essentially, the competition is of an economic nature, Most countries in Southeast Asia are interested in economic development, and one more power, in this case China, which could help in this field, would be welcome.

    The economic competition in Southeast Asia is made all the more complex by two factors, namely. China coming in with a market of 700 million people will increase the competition with other big powers. This naturally will increase attention by the United States to her economic interests when the Vietnam war is over. Therefore, there will then be a new situation with new vistas for all to watch and make the necessary adjustments. It would in our opinion, be as if a new and powerful neighbour has come to do business in the old neighbourhood.

3.03 p.m.

    Mr Teong Eng Siong (Sembawang)(In Mandarin): Mr Speaker, Sir, I support the motion expressing our thanks to the President's speech. The President made a policy speech in this House on the 21st of last month and this has added a new page in our nation-building history. In his policy speech, the President has painted a beautiful picture of our achievements. He has also laid down correct directives in regard to our future task of nation-building. He has also laid stress on the importance of strengthening our defence capability in order to ensure our security and stability. Undeniably, this is what we should do to ensure our independence and sovereignty. When we gained our independences, some six years ago. I remember there were people who expressed doubts about our ability to maintain our security and sovereignty. However, after these six years of independence, we have achieved great progress in our defence capability. This is due to the concerted efforts of our people in co-operating with the Government. As the President has pointed out in his speech, we must be viable in our defence. Through the Commonwealth

Column: 108

Five-Power defence arrangements, security and stability are assured for several, years ahead. We must make use of this time to consolidate our defence capability. It is true that in this task we should exert great efforts. Our national service youths have put up an excellent performance in our National Day celebrations. Everyone of them is well-disciplined. Therefore, I believe our youth will be able to take up the task of defending our country.

    Besides the defence of our country, the maintenance of stability and the' development of our economy is also very important. Only in a stable environment can we have more investment, thereby creating more opportunities `if employment and raising the standard of living of our people.

    Sir, in the President's policy speech, mention has been made of higher rates, of compensation for those people affected by resettlement. This is a very correct measure. We know that the Government's urban renewal scheme is in the long-term interest of our country. Therefore, it needs the full support of all the people. On the other hand, we must also give sympathetic consideration to people affected by resettlement so that they may not suffer any great loss. So the Government's decision to increase the rates of compensation and ex gratia payments is a measure that we all should praise and support.

    I will now go through the various topics in the addendum to the President's speech. Mention has been made of the allocation of $5 million to resettle the hawkers in various parts of the island. The plan involves the building of market centres to accommodate the hawkers. This is undoubtedly a good plan because it will provide fixed localities for them to carry on their business, and also to enable members of the public to enjoy their food in a more congenial environment. I am sure this plan will meet with the approval of all the people, particularly the hawkers. In fact, the hawker centres around Farrer Road Circus and Newton Circus have given members of the public a very

Column: 109

good impression because of their modern facilities and healthy surroundings. Thus more customers patronise them and, in this way, their business is improved. As a result, more hawker complexes will be built by the Government. This will be good news to the hawkers. We all know that lots of them lead a difficult life. They have to hawk under the hot sun and in heavy rain. In the past, they have been neglected. However, ever since the People's Action Party came to power, they have been better looked after. In the past few years, many new market and hawker centres have been built in Housing and Development Board estates for hawkers to do their business. Now that the Government is allotting a sum of $5 million to improve the hawker sites, more benefit and business will come to them. Therefore, it is a wise and judicious measure. It is also a concrete example that the Government has done something for the good of the hawkers.

    Sir, in the addendum regarding the Ministry of Law and National Development, it is mentioned that the Housing and Development Board plans to build 100,000 housing units for the period 1971 to 1975. This will double the target it has achieved in the past. In spite of this rapid building plan, however, we are still short of housing accommodation. The measures taken by the Government have solved some of the acute housing problems. The hire-purchase ownership plan of the Government has solved the problem of housing to a great extent. This plan has been well received by the people. However. I would like to ask whether the Government can also extend this sort of hire-purchase terms to renters of H.D.B, shop premises. I agree fully with what the Member for Thomson has said in this House the other day about giving the occupiers of Housing and Development Board shop premises certain hire-purchase facilities to buy shop premises.     In regard to any supervision or regulation of take-overs, my Ministry is faced , with a number of conflicting considerations:

    (a) It is desirable that inefficient companies should be taken over by more competent companies.

    (b) There should not be unnecessary interference in takeovers where companies willingly merge.

    (c) Consolidation by way of merging into larger economic units bring economies of scale.

    (d) The fear that there may be a concentration of economic power in the hands of one group giving rise to monopoly or near monopoly conditions.

    Our present policy is not to discriminate against foreign interests buying into Singapore companies generally, and in so far as Sterling area residents are concerned, there are no exchange controls on such transactions. However, it might now be opportune to prepare for an increase in take-over activities and also consider whether certain categories of Singapore companies should be kept under Singapore control, for example, banks and insurance companies. It is not suggested that foreign interests be totally, excluded in respect of such companies. On the contrary, minority foreign equity participation might even be encouraged if it increases the efficiency and competitiveness of the local company. Nevertheless, control by some system of vetting foreign participation in

Column: 116

certain designated sectors of commerce and industry may be necessary and desirable. Perhaps also some equivalent to the London Panel on Take-overs and Mergers" is required This Panel has drawn up a set of rules and established a code of behaviour which all parties to a take-over are expected to observe. Essentially the Code drawn up by the London Panel seeks to ensure early disclosure of details of a bid so that all shareholders are placed on an equal footing as far as possible, and to ensure that the majority shareholders do not exploit their position at the expense of the minority.

    The other system of regulation is that established by the American Securities Exchange Commission. However, their approach is more cumbersome and a number of countries. France. Switzerland and Japan, have been examining the London Panel's mode of operation in preference to the American system. In Singapore it is probable that the London Panel type o approach modified to take into account local conditions may be more appropriate. This must be examined in relation to the Companies Act and the Securities Industries Act which are patterned on Australian legislation. I am advised that the Australian Companies Act has been recently amended to deal with takeovers in much greater detail, and these amendments might prove of help in drafting similar regulations for Singapore.

    It is proposed that the Ministry of Finance and the Monetary Authority should, in conjunction with the Attorney-General, examine whether further amendments to the Companies Act to deal with take-overs are necessary or desirable, and whether a London Panel type of institution can play a role in developing an acceptable code of conduct and standards of behaviour in take-overs and mergers.
